instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message:
This device does turn on just fine with the battery connnected.
Now if i connect the charger in one of the two ports  it shows me 5.2V and 0amp.
On the other one it doenst even show me a voltage. 

Without the battery connected it has 5.2V input and approx. 300ma of current consumption on both usb-c ports. (PPBUS around 12.25V)

I have already tried to flash it in DFU mode.

This device had liquid damage.

i have already changed the following: -<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> because it had a short.
i have already reflowed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message:
Different behaviour on USB-C ports denotes that you have problem on that area.
If board works good with battery alone, your problem is clearly in the USB-C area.
Compare diode mode readings on LDO rails of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

Also check diode mode on CC1/2 pins of dead USB-C port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message: both <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips show almost same diode mode readings on LDO Rails and CC1/CC2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message:
Do you still have a "dead" USB-C port?
Compare readings on the input pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message: if i have no battery connected both behave the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message:
Should have same behoaviour on both chips, no matter battery present, or not.
If not, then still have problem with one port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesnt charge.
threads.message: i have changed one usb-c chip and it works now. thank you alot :)
